titlestmt.subtitle: A Finding Aid to the Raymond Gloeckler Papers, 1952-2008, in the Archives of American Art
titlestmt.author: by Erin Kinhart

publicationstmt.publisher: Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by Erin Kinhart on September 27, 2011

did.head: Collection Overview

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution

did.abstract: The papers of Wisconsin printmaker and educator Raymond Gloeckler measure 1.4 linear feet and date from 1952 to 2008. Gloeckler's career is documented through biographical material, correspondence with galleries and art organizations, exhibition and commission files, printed material, and artwork.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The papers were donated in 2010 by Raymond Gloeckler.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The Raymond Gloeckler papers were processed to a minimum level by Erin Kinhart in 2011.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Raymond Gloeckler papers, 1952-2008. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Use of original papers requires an appointment.

userestrict.head: Ownership and Literary Rights
userestrict.p: The Raymond Gloeckler papers are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Literary rights as possessed by the donor have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship. The collection is subject to all copyright laws.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Raymond Gloeckler (1928- ) is a printmaker and educator in Madison, Wisconsin. Gloeckler was born on December 13, 1928 in Portage, Wisconsin. He attended the University of Wisconsin, Madison, receiving his B.S. in 1950 and his M.S. in 1952. After holding several teaching positions at colleges in Michigan, he returned to the University of Wisconsin, Madison, in 1961 as a professor and taught there until his retirement in 1993. Gloeckler established himself as a leading figure in 20th-century woodcuts and wood engraving, exhibiting his works nationally and internationally, and receiving numerous awards.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The papers of Wisconsin printmaker and educator Raymond Gloeckler measure 1.4 linear feet and date from 1952 to 2008. Gloeckler's career as an artist is documented through biographical material, correspondence with galleries and art organizations, exhibition and commission files, printed material, and artwork.

Biographical material includes a professional application, award certificates, and biographical documentation compiled for the book Progressive Printmakers: Wisconsin Artists and the Print Renaissance. The bulk of Gloeckler's correspondence consists of handmade holiday and greeting cards sent to him from friends and fellow printmakers including Warrington Colescott, Rosemary Feit Covey, Arthur Geisert, William Haendel, Mary Meyer, and David Rynning. Also found is scattered correspondence regarding the sale and exhibition of his work. Exhibition and commission files only document select projects and may include notes, correspondence, exhibition lists, and agreements. Printed material consists chronological files containing newspaper and magazine clippings, exhibition announcements and catalogs, newsletters, university publications, and brochures. Also found are three limited edition books containing prints by Gloeckler. This collection also contains two pencil drawings and four holiday prints by Gloeckler.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged as 5 series:

list.item: Series 3: Exhibition and Commission Files, 1959-1994 (Box 1; 9 folders)

controlaccess.head: Names and Subject Terms
controlaccess.p: This collection is indexed in the online catalog of the Archives of American Art under the following terms:

scopecontent.p: Found here are award certificates and an application for promotion which contains details of Raymond Gloeckler's professional activities up to 1959. Also included are various biographical materials compiled for Progressive Printmakers: Wisconsin Artists and the Print Renaissance. Within these files are biographical notes, slides, lists of prints by Gloeckler, excerpts from a 1993 interview, artist statements, correspondence regarding the publication, and draft text.

did.unittitle: Application for Promotion, Eastern Michigan University, 1959
Material compiled for Progressive Printmakers: Wisconsin Artists and the Print Renaissance, circa 1993-1999

scopecontent.p: Gloeckler's correspondence is with the Butler Institute of Art, Cincinnati Art Museum, and other galleries and art organizations. Letters primarily concern the sale or exhibiton of his prints. Also found within the general correspondence are a few letters from friends. The bulk of this series consists of handmade holiday and greeting cards sent to Gloeckler from friends and fellow printmakers including Warrington Colescott, Rosemary Feit Covey, Arthur Geisert, William Haendel, Mary Meyer, David Rynning, and others.

arrangement.p: Holiday and greeting cards are arranged in alphabetical order followed by a folder of cards from unidentified senders.

did.unittitle: Correspondence with Butler Institute of American Art, 1965

scopecontent.p: Found here are commission and exhibition files maintained by Gloeckler for select projects. Within these files may be notes, correspondence, exhibition lists, agreements, and printed material. Of note is a file of correspondence, lists of artwork, and other details regarding his 1980 retrospective exhibition at the Milwaukee Art Center.

did.unittitle: Exhibitions, British Society of Wood Engravers, 1985-1992
Exhibition, Milwaukee Art Center, Raymond Gloeckler: A Retrospective, 1979-1980

scopecontent.p: Printed material includes three limited edition books containing prints by Gloeckler and two books of poetry by Dik Schwanke. Also found are chronological files containing various printed material kept by Gloeckler to document his professional activities. These files include newspaper and magazine clippings, exhibition announcements and catalogs, newsletters, university publications, and brochures.

did.unittitle: Books, Everyday Stuff and or am i so strange by Dik Schwanke,
Book, Raymond Gloeckler: The Engravers Cut, 2001
Book, Snippets by N. F. Simpson, 2006
Catalog, People Reading: Selections from the Collection of Donald and Patricia Oresman, 2007-2008

scopecontent.p: This series contains two pencil drawings by Gloeckler, four holiday prints created by Gloeckler, and three wood engravings by Earl Nitschke, printed by the Enigma Press.

did.unittitle: Pencil Drawings by Raymond Gloeckler, undated
Holiday Prints by Raymond Gloeckler, 1980, undated
Wood Engravings by Earl Nitschke, circa 2004
